div.p: CHRONPROSE is an element within CHRONSTRUCT, preceded by a DATE element and available throughout the textbase, that briefly relates the essential facts of a chronology event. It should contain no more than one or two pithy sentences so that its appearance will be suitable to the layout and conceptual framing of either print or electronic chronologies. Try to work in words that may be the subject of searches, the kind we used to put in KEYWORDCLASS (atrocity, celebration, climate, first).

div.codeblock: Always use full past tense in a CHRONPROSE element rather than telegraphic style: <CHRONPROSE>The term suffragette was first used in the Daily Mail.</CHRONPROSE> In this example, the expression "was first used" is preferable to "first used."

div.p: Should I repeat the date of a chronology event inside the CHRONPROSE? As a rule, no. However, there may be times when you feel you need to contextualize a date or provide an alternative or extra date in your CHRONPROSE. Feel free to do this, tagging the date only if you feel it vital that it be tagged from the research/retrieval perspective, but make sure that the date you want the chronology item to be sorted under is the DATE element of your CHRONSTRUCT.
